text: In a boy with a severe form of HSD10 deficiency (300438), Rauschenberger et al. (2010) identified a hemizygous c.257A-G transition in exon 3 of the HSD17B10 gene, resulting in an asp86-to-gly (D86G) substitution. Patient fibroblasts showed about 30% residual enzymatic activity. The patient had absent neurologic development and died of progressive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy at age 7 months. Patient cells showed punctate and fragmented mitochondrial organization. Transfection of D86G-mutated HSD17B10 into HSD17B10-null cells failed to rescue apoptosis. The findings suggested that the mutation causes a defect in mitochondrial function, which is responsible for clinical features of the disorder.
